div.sent: What is sound?
We know energy has many forms.
We can feel some forms of energy through our senses.
Heat energy gives us the sensation of hot and cold while light energy gives us the sensation of vision.
Similarly, the form of energy that gives us the sensation of hearing is called sound.
Sound is produced as a result of vibration.
Some of the sounds are mild some are strong;
some are sweet and some are hard;
some sound pleases us some annoy us.
How are they produced?
Take a cup made of brass or any other metal and strike it with an iron spoon.
A metalic sound will be heard.
The sound will not cease at once but will be heard for some time.
The sound will be fainter and fainter before it is not heard anymore.
Again strike the cup but this time you touch it just after striking it.
What you feel?
You feel that the cup is vibrating and the vibrating stops as soon as you touch the cup with your hand.
The sound will be heard no longer.
It seems that as if there is a relation between sound and vibration.
Yes there is.
Sound is produced due to vibration of a body.
This vibration is so rapid that normally one can not see it with naked eyes but can feel it by touching.
Beat a drum with stick, the vibration of the skin diaphragm produces sound.
When playing on a guitar, the vibration of the strings makes the sound.
If you blow a pipe, there is vibration in the air inside the pipe and sound is heard.
Place your fingers gently on your throat and then talk, you will feel vibration.
Stop talking the vibration stops too.
Inside our throat there is larynx.
There are two light diaphragms in our larynx which are called vocal chords.
When we talk, there is vibration in the vocal chords and sound is produced.
If you want more proof of the fact that vibration produces sounds, then do the following experiment.
You need a tuning fork to do this experiment.
Tuning fork is an U-shaped steel rod with a handle.
Strike the fork with a hammer padded with rubber, you will hear sound.
You also need a pith ball very light ball made of wood pith.
Suspend this ball with thread and touch an arm of the tuning fork with pith ball.
You will see that the ball is being pushed by the fork arm again and again.
Touch the arm by hand you will feel its vibration.
As you touch, vibration stops and the sound stops too.
So the experiment proves that vibration is the cause of sound.
We have seen that sound is produced by vibration of bodies.
But how does it reach our ears from a distance?
It comes through air.
Air is the medium through which sound travels through and reach our ears.
There is a light diaphragm in our ear.
Sound vibration enters in and vibrates this diaphragm.
When this vibration is carried to our brain, we hear the sound Does the sound travel through air only?
No, sound also passes through other gaseous medium.
Even it can travel through solid and liquid medium too.
Stick your ear at one end of an iron or wooden bench and tell your friend to make sound at the other end.
You will hear a clear sound.
You see a railway engine coming toward you.
The sound is not yet audible.
Stick your ear to the railway line and the sound will be heard.
While taking a bath in a pond, dive and talk to some one diving at a distance.
He will hear your voice.
Fill a balloon with water, stick ear at one side and rub at the other.
Sound of rubbing is heard.
Can sound pass through a vacuum?
No, because who will carry sound vibration if there is no medium.
The body whose vibration makes sound vibrates the medium with it.
Vibration passes from one layer to other layer.
If there is no medium no sound is transmitted.
Therefore for transmission of sound some sort of medium is necessary-be it in the form of solid, liquid or gas.
There is no air on the moon.
So when astronauts reach there, they only see the movement of their lips but can't hear each other.
The source of a sound is the vibration of a body.
But how does sound transmit through air?
The vibration of a body means it goes in one direction, stops for a moment and then goes in the opposite direction;
again stops for a while and repeats its motion.
Thus a vibration is made up of a to and fro motion.
Thus the vibrating body alternately compresses and rarefies the air layer attached to the front of the body.
Thus the compression and rarefaction of the air spread from the source of sound in all directions, that is, the sound is transmitted.
Say, a tuning fork vibrates and produces sound.
For our understanding the air before the fork may be taken as divided into a number of thin air layers.
This compressed air layer compresses the next layer.
Thus compressed layers are produced one after another as long as the fork moves to right.
When the arm comes back to left towards B, the pressure on the attached layer decreases.
As a result the layer now is rarefied ).
The Rarefied layer goes after the compressed air produced before.
They all moved forward.
Thus vibration of tuning fork creates compression and rarefaction alternately.
Such alternate compression and rarefaction in air caused by vibration of sounds is called sound wave.
It goes in all direction as waves of compression and rarefaction.
Remember, no air particle actually moves from place to place and carries sound;
they only vibrate to and for about their fixed positions.
They produce compression and rarefaction which carry sound as waves.
Also remember that sound is a kind of energy and the carrier of this energy is the sound wave.
It will be clearer if we try to understand what a wave is.
Take a large basin full of water.
Drop a stone in it.
You will see that high and low waves of water are produced.
The waves are spreading in all directions up to the sides of the basin.
Place a small paper boat on the wave; it vibrates up and down at the same place.
Some energy is necessary for making the boat vibrate.
Where does this energy come from?
It is the stone which gives this energy.
The stone creates vibration in the water particles of that place.
This vibration goes from that place to the adjacent places of still water particles and forms waves.
These waves carry energy too in the form of wave.
In this way the energy which produced vibration at a place is transferred to another place.
Wave is a mechanism of carrying energy from one place to another.
Take a rope and tie one end to a pole.
Hold the other end with your hand and shake it.
Each part of the rope will move up and down and produce waves.
The waves thus produced goes from one end of the rope to the other end but no part of the rope changes its place.
The wave carries energy of your hand to other place.
How does a sound wave move?
You may have a clear idea, if you alternately compress and expand a spring.
First compress and then extend it; wave of compression and extension is produced.
sound wave moves through the air in this fashion.
Extend your both hands and move them up and down.
Does your movement of hands produce sound?
Of course it does; because all vibrations make sound.
But you could not hear the sound as all sounds are not heard.
A source of sound vibrates and produces sound.
Vibration means sound source moves to and fro again and again.
Starting from one end when the vibrating body goes to the other end and comes back to the starting point, it completes one full vibration.
The number of complete vibration done in one second by a body is called frequency.
Our ears can not hear the sounds produced by all vibrations.
It is seen that sound having frequency of less than 20 and above 20,000 can not produce the sense of hearing in our ears.
This sound is known as ultrasonic sound.
If the frequency of vibration is between 20 and 20,000 per second, it can produce audible sound.
The sounds produced within this range of frequency are known as infrasonic sound.
It is to be remembered that this range of audible frequency is not the same for all people.
Most adult person can hear sound having frequency ranging 25 to 18,For children this frequency range is greater.
You may have noticed that all people do not hear equally.
Again the audibility range is not the same for all animals.
Dog, cat, bat and titmouse can hear sound of frequency more than 20.
There is a flute which produces sound of frequency more than 20.
Men can not hear this sound but dog hears it and comes to his master.
Bats can produce ultrasonic sound and move in the dark using this sound though it can not see things.
In thunder we see the flashes of light first and then hear sound.
Why don't we see the light and hear the sound at the same time?
Sound takes longer time than light to reach us.
The velocity of light is much higher than that of sound.
When you watch cricket match from a distance, you see the bat hitting the ball before your hear the sound of hitting.
Watch gun firing from a distance and you will see the smoke of firing first and the sound of firing afterward.
All these examples indicate that sound takes time to cover a distance, that is, sound has got certain velocity.
the distance covered by sound in one second is called the velocity of sound.
Velocity of sound depends on the nature of medium.
Also it depends on its temperature and density.
For example, at the temperature of 0 degree celsius sound travels 332 metre in a second in air.
But it covers 350 m/s at 300c in air.
In water sound has more than 4 21 times greater velocity than in air which is nearly 1500 m/s.
sound moves through steel with a velocity of 5000 m/s, nearly 15 times greater than that in air.
Generally velocity of sound is the highest in solid medium and least in gaseous medium.
Stand about 20 metre from a tall building in a calm and quiet place and clap your hands.
You will hear someone replying to your clapping immediately after.
At the mouth of a deep well speak aloud downward, you will hear the same voice speaking from bellow.
This repetition of sound is called echo.
Reflection of sound produces echo.
It is like reflection of light in a mirror.
This is known as reflection of sound.
Repetition of sound due to reflection is called echo.
Reflection of sound obeys the laws of reflection of light.
The exception is, while plain, smooth and shining surfaces are good reflectors of light, extended, hard and solid surfaces are better for reflection of sound.
So hills, mountains and tall buildings produce echo of sound.
Sound takes time to go to reflector and come back and that is why echo is heard some time after the sound is made.
When we talk in a room, are the sounds of our conversation reflected by the walls?
Yes they are but why do not we hear any echoing sound?
In this time sound travels twice between reflector and listener.
If the room temperature is taken as 300 C, the velocity of sound in air is about 350 m/s.
In 101 th of a second sound covers 35 metres.
So if the reflecting walls are at half of this distance i.e. 17.5 m, echo will be hard.
However, normal room measures less than this and therefore no echo is heard.
But in a large hall room if speeches and musical function take place you may hear the echo of those sounds.
Therefore the walls of cinema hall and auditorium are covered with soft load pads and the floor is covered with carpet.
Soft materials reflect little sound and absorb more, thus help control the echo.
Due to repeated reflection of sound in different layers of cloud in the sky the rumbling sound of thunder is heard.
A bat produces high frequency sound when it flies.
This sound is reflected by any obstacles in its way which produces echoes.
Hearing these echoes the bat avoids the obstacles on its way and flies in dark safely.
Music pleases our ears, refreshes mind and makes us cheerful.
But if all the time music is played by a loudspeaker, it irritates us instead of giving pleasure.
High volume sound is a torture to our ear.
We can not work or pay attention to our studies.
Even we sometimes engage in quarrels with the person who makes this nonsense.
A sudden loud sound startles us and pulpits our heart.
Loud sounds may cause a person with weak heart even to die.
Continuous loud sound damages and may rapture our ear diaphragms.
Through experiments gradual loss of hearing is found among the labourers working in a factory which produces much noise.
Those who work for ten years in a noisy environment may lose 50% of their hearing ability.
It increases the risks ulcer and other intestinal diseases.
In brief, excessive and high sound causes harms to us physically and mentally.
The hydraulic horn used by the motor vehicles is also very harmful.
It is one of the reasons for creating sound pollutions in busy cities like Dhaka.
We should be aware of the dangers caused by sound pollution.
Some music shops play music very loudly all day long.
In the streets people use mikes for various purposes such as to sell lottery tickets or medicines or to announce some events.
These are harmful to our health.
We must develop awareness among people regarding the adverse effects of sound.
You also must not play radio, cassette player or CD player in high volume.
Do not use the earphones of your walkman all day long.
The drivers of cars have to be aware of the proper use of horns and we must avoid using hydraulic horns here and there.
We always use sound in our day to day life.
We use sound in our conversation, in songs and music, in the programmes of radio and television.
Besides, there are special uses of sounds.
Three practical uses of sound are described below.
Echo produced by reflection of sound is used to determine the depth of sea.
A short, sharp sound wave is sent towards the bottom of a sea from a ship on it.
The sound wave is reflected at the bottom of the sea and comes back to the ship.
In this method sound is produced by an electric machine and the reflected sound is also recorded electrically.
The interval of time between sending and receiving sound is also recorded in an automatic system.
The sound used in this experiment is an ultrasonic sound wave because ultrasonic sound travels in a straight line, without being scattered or absorbed.
Doctors examine your chest by an instrument called stethoscope.
There is a round shaped part of the instrument which doctors places on your chest.
This small round shaped part contains a thin diaphragm in it which is vibrated by the movement of your heart.
The sound of vibration reaches to the ears of doctor by two rubber tubes attached to the round part.
The sound goes forward through the pipe with repeated reflections.
As the sound travels through the tube it can not spread outside and the doctor can clearly hear the sounds of your heart movements.
All musical instruments like harmonium, piano, guitar, violin, drums etc. produce sound through vibrations of certain frequency.
They use sounds of different frequencies for creating tunes.
Air vibration produces musical sound in flute, harmonium and piano.
In drums and tabla vibration of the leather membrane produces sound.
In sitar, guitar and violin vibration of strings make sound.
The quality of sound depends on its frequency.
Lower frequency sounds are flat, grave and harsh while higher frequency sounds are delicate and soft.
Men's voice is flat for lower frequency and female voice is shrill for its high frequency.
